title: (x) Police Line: Do Not Cross tape - Helvetica Inserat {Stephen}
content:
Is the font used in the yellow "Police Line: Do Not Cross" Arial or Helvetica? Or is it something less common?

Here's the first image I found through image searching.  
 [http://www.flickr.com/photos/dotpolka/83025846/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150326030955/http:/www.flickr.com/photos/dotpolka/83025846/ "http://www.flickr.com/photos/dotpolka/83025846/")

But judging from the image search results, it seems that there's an inconsistency in the type used?
author: chimerical

comments.content: I'm sure there are different manufacturers of this tape. This one is less typographically correct than others I've seen. It's a [squooshed](http://web.archive.org/web/20150326030955/http:/www.typophile.com/wiki/squooshed) [Helvetica Inserat](http://web.archive.org/web/20150326030955/http:/www.fontshop.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=catalog.fontdetail&displayfontid=LH.120906.0.24&attributes.sampleSize=48&sampleText=POLICE+LINE+DO+NOT+CROSS&sampleSize=24).

Hi, I am the person who took the picture. The police line tape I photographed was a movie prop. It is possible that it is not the original tape used by police, which would explain the odd typography. Hope this helped.
